addressleaf.section:
To the right honorable my very singular good Lord
e Erle of Essex./

page.lettertext:
fol.105r
May it please yo
r
good L. Besides
at w
ch
I have
written unto my
L. T
re
r
, wherof I send
e copie to yo
r
L.
heerew
t
, I have litle other mater to signifie presently.
Coronel Murrey
, of whome I have written in my last of
the 14 though he beare
e affection of a dutifull subject
unto him, yet he makes it a cleere case,
at if this succo
r
of
mony, w
ch
Co. Stuart
doth require, shall be drawen from
the
States,
it will be wholy devided among some about the
King: being suche as partly neede it, and partly (as the
Chancello
r
)
that have lent unto
e King. And therfor
as a practise by abusing
e K. to make their privat be-
nefit, he would not willingly have it speede: still he doth
persist in his former assertion, and affirmeth up
o
knowledge
that
e K. hath no neede of any suche aide, as
e States
are made beleeve. For were it so, that it were his desire,
or that it had bin heeretofore, to sup presse these Erles of
his contrey, they had ether bin taken, or slaine, or chased
out of Scotland a great while agoe. But what cause
he alleageth, why it is not effected, I shewed yo
r
L. in
my last. It were too long to hold yo
r
L. with
rehersal of discourses, w
ch
I have had w
t
divers persons,
and w
t
Barnevelt
in special, about
e Scottishe de-
mandes, but though I finde them very forward to gra-
tifie
e King, yet I hope I have obtained by way of
good persuasions, and intimation of some perils, that they
will nether take his part in any dangerous practise, nor
second him otherwise in any action at all, if it be of impor-
tance, unles they notifie
e same to her
Ma
tie
before.
And thus I take my humble leave. From
e Hage.
Fe
b
22 1594.
Yo
r
L. most humbly bounden Tho. Bodley
